q: What are some common causes of hip pain?
a: Some common causes of hip pain include sudden injury, arthritis (such as osteoarthritis or rheumatoid arthritis), sprains or strains, joint infections, and hip fractures.

q: How can I ease hip pain?
a: To ease hip pain, you can try avoiding strain on your hip, using ice packs, taking painkillers like paracetamol or ibuprofen, wearing comfortable shoes, losing weight if overweight, and doing gentle hip stretching exercises.

q: When should I see a GP for hip pain?
a: You should see a GP for hip pain if it is stopping you from doing normal activities, affecting your sleep, getting worse or recurring, or if the pain has not improved after treating it at home for two weeks.

q: What should I do if I have severe hip pain and other concerning symptoms?
a: If you have severe hip pain that started suddenly without any fall or injury, along with swelling, change in skin color, feeling unwell, high temperature, or tingling/loss of feeling in your hip or leg, you should seek urgent medical attention by calling NHS 111 or going to A&E.

q: What treatments are available for hip pain?
a: Treatment for hip pain depends on the cause. A GP might prescribe stronger painkillers, recommend exercises or refer you for physiotherapy, suggest occupational therapy for aids like walking sticks, or refer you to a specialist who may consider options like steroid injections or hip replacement.

q: Do I need a hip replacement if other treatments don't help with hip pain caused by a damaged hip joint?
a: In some cases, if other treatments do not provide relief for hip pain caused by a damaged hip joint, a hip replacement surgery may be necessary.

q: What are the symptoms of hip fracture?
a: The symptoms of hip fracture include severe pain and the inability to walk after a fall or injury.

q: What exercises can help with hip pain?
a: Versus Arthritis provides exercises specifically designed to help with hip pain. You can find more information on their website.

q: What does severe pain mean?
a: Severe pain refers to pain that is always present and so intense that it makes it hard to think or talk. It may also cause difficulty in sleeping, moving, and performing daily activities.

q: When should I call 999 or go to A&E for hip pain?
a: You should call 999 or go to A&E immediately if you have severe hip pain after a fall or injury, are unable to walk or put weight on your leg, or experience tingling or loss of feeling in your hip or leg after an injury.

q: What are some common causes of hip pain?
a: Some common causes of hip pain include sprain or strain from intense or repetitive exercise, osteoarthritis, rheumatoid arthritis, joint infection, and hip fracture.

q: How can I ease hip pain?
a: To ease hip pain, you can try avoiding excessive strain on your hip, applying an ice pack to the painful area, using painkillers like paracetamol or ibuprofen, wearing comfortable shoes, and doing gentle hip stretching exercises.

q: When should I see a GP for hip pain?
a: You should see a GP for hip pain if it is stopping you from doing normal activities, getting worse or recurring, not improving after 2 weeks of home treatment, or if you have hip stiffness for more than 30 minutes after waking up.

q: What should I do in case of severe hip pain?
a: In case of severe hip pain without a fall or injury, you should seek an urgent GP appointment or get help from NHS 111 if your hip is swollen, the skin around it has changed color, or if you feel generally unwell with a high temperature.

q: What are some treatments for hip pain?
a: Treatments for hip pain depend on the underlying cause. A GP may prescribe stronger painkillers, recommend exercises or physiotherapy, refer you to an occupational therapist, or discuss treatments like steroid injections and surgery.

q: What are some exercises for hip pain?
a: You can refer to Versus Arthritis for exercises specifically designed for the hips.

q: What can an occupational therapist help with in relation to hip pain?
a: An occupational therapist can help with things to make your life easier, such as walking sticks or walking aids.

q: When may someone need a hip replacement for hip pain?
a: A person with pain caused by a damaged hip joint may eventually need a hip replacement if other treatments do not provide relief.

q: What immediate action should be taken for severe hip pain after a fall or injury?
a: In case of severe hip pain after a fall or injury, immediate action is required. You should call 999 or go to A&E if you're unable to walk or put weight on your leg, or if you experience tingling or loss of feeling in your hip or leg.

q: Where can I find my nearest A&E department?
a: You can find your nearest A&E department by searching online or using a hospital directory.
